title: 111_s3687
content: The Act may be cited as the "Royalty Relief for American Consumers Act of 2010" and pertains to eligibility for new leases and the transfer of leases. The "Royalty Relief for American Consumers Act of 2010" prohibits issuing new leases for oil or gas production unless existing leases are renegotiated to include royalty payments based on price thresholds. Lessees must comply to be eligible for new leases. The "Royalty Relief for American Consumers Act of 2010" requires lessees to hold a covered lease or have an interest in it to be eligible for new leases. If multiple lessees own a share of a covered lease, the Secretary may implement separate rules. The Secretary may implement separate agreements with lessees of a covered lease to modify payment responsibilities, including price thresholds. Shares under the agreement will not be considered a covered lease for lessees. Transfers can be made by lessees or other individuals with a direct interest. (b) Transfers of covered leases in the Gulf of Mexico under the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act are restricted for lessees or individuals with a direct interest unless they renegotiate the lease to include specified price thresholds. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act restricts transfers of covered leases in the Gulf of Mexico unless lessees agree to include price thresholds for royalty relief. Amounts received from rentals or royalties under these leases are to be used for deficit reduction or reducing the Federal debt. The term "covered lease" refers to a lease for oil or gas production in the Gulf of Mexico that meets specific criteria and is not subject to certain royalty relief limitations. The term "lessee" includes any person involved in the lease. The term "lessee" includes any person or entity that controls, is controlled by, or is in common control with a lessee. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary of the Interior can amend leases for Gulf of Mexico tracts from 1996 to 2000 to include price thresholds for royalty suspension provisions. These thresholds must align with specified criteria and will be effective from October 1, 2010. Existing lease terms remain until September 30, 2010.
